facts.text: Appeal is Civil Appeal No. 13 of 1958 by special leave from judgment and order dated June 29, 1954 of Nagpur High Court in Misc. Civil Case No. 219 of 1952

anchor.surface_text: CIVIL APPELLATE JURISDICTION Civil Appeal No. 13 of 1958. Appeal by special leave from the judgment and order dated June 29, 1954, of the former Nagpur High Court in Misc. Civil Case No. 219 of 1952.

facts.text: Reference to High Court by Board of Revenue under s. 23(1) of the Central Provinces Berar Sales Tax Act, 1947

anchor.surface_text: answering against the appellant certain questions referred to it by the Board of Revenue under s. 23 1  of the Central Provinces Berar Sales Tax Act, 1947  hereinafter referred to as the Act . The reference arose out of an order of assessment made on the respondent for payment of sales tax for the period June 1, 1947, to November 12, 1947, on a taxable turnover of Rs. 30,067-9-0.

facts.text: Assessment order on respondent for sales tax period June 1, 1947 to November 12, 1947 on turnover of Rs. 30,067-9-0

anchor.surface_text: The reference arose out of an order of assessment made on the respondent for payment of sales tax for the period June 1, 1947, to November 12, 1947, on a taxable turnover of Rs. 30,067-9-0. The facts leading up to the present -appeal may shortly be stated as follows.

facts.text: Respondent deals in matchwood called sawar Bombay-Malabaricum with place of business at Chanda in erstwhile Central Provinces

anchor.surface_text: The respondent deals in matchwood called sawar  Bombay- Malabaricum . His place of business is situate at Chanda in the erstwhile Central Provinces. In January 1948 the respondent entered into an agreement with the Western India Match Co. Ltd., which is popularly known and will hereinafter be referred to as WIMCO for the supply of a minimum quantity of 2,500 tons of sawar logs during the season 1947-48.

facts.text: Respondent entered into agreement with WIMCO in January 1948 for supply of minimum 2500 tons of sawar logs during season 1947-48 evidenced by WIMCO letter dated January 7, 1948

anchor.surface_text: In January 1948 the respondent entered into an agreement with the Western India Match Co. Ltd., which is popularly known and will hereinafter be referred to as WIMCO for the supply of a minimum quantity of 2,500 tons of sawar logs during the season 1947-48. This agreement is evidenced by WIMCOs letter dated January 7, 1948, accepting and companyfirming it.

facts.text: Agreement subject to formal contract dated March 2, 1945 renewed from year to year on common ground

anchor.surface_text: It is companymon ground, however, that the agreement of sale was subject to the companyditions appearing in a formal companytract in writing dated March 2, 1945, which is said to have been renewed from year to year. It appears that prior to the execution of the last mentioned companytract there was another companytract between the respondent and WIMCO which was dated October 18, 1940.

facts.text: Prior contract between respondent and WIMCO dated October 18, 1940 superseded by 1945 contract

anchor.surface_text: It appears that prior to the execution of the last mentioned companytract there was another companytract between the respondent and WIMCO which was dated October 18, 1940. Evidently that companytract was superseded by the later one of March 2, 1945, the terms and companyditions whereof were renewed year after year.

facts.text: Respondent despatched sawar logs by railway from Chanda or other stations in Central Provinces to Ambernath in Bombay

anchor.surface_text: Pursuant to the agreement between the respondent and WIMCO, the former loaded diverse quantities of Sawar logs on railway wagons and despatched the same by railway from Chanda or other railway stations in the Central Provinces to Ambernath in the erstwhile province of Bombay and outside the Central Provinces.

facts.text: WIMCO representative present at railway station on many occasions when logs were sorted and loaded, not disputed

anchor.surface_text: It is number disputed that on many occasions the representative of WIMCO was present at the railway station when the logs were sorted out and loaded into the wagons. The statement of the case submitted along with the reference under s. 23 1  of the Act is silent on the point as to whether the railway receipts were made out with WIMCO as the companysignee

facts.text: Railway receipts taken in name of consignee WIMCO, not disputed before court

anchor.surface_text: but it is abundantly clear from the order of the Assistant Commissioner, Sales Tax, which is part of the record -and it has number been disputed before us- that the railway receipt which is a document of title according to s. 2 4  of the Indian Sale of Goods Act is taken in the name of the companysignee.

facts.text: On arrival at Ambernath, WIMCO paid railway freight, inspected and measured logs by Factory Manager, paid prices to respondent's agent at Bombay

anchor.surface_text: The companyrse of dealings between the parties also appears to be that, on arrival of the logs at Ambernath, the companysignee buyer WIMCO, paid the railway freight and the logs were inspected and measured by WIMCOs Factory Manager and the prices, calculated at the agreed rates, were paid to the respondents agent at Bombay.

facts.text: Price of logs supplied and accepted by WIMCO during period amounted to Rs. 30,067-9-0, no doubt

anchor.surface_text: There is numberdoubt that the price of the logs supplied by the respondent to WIMCO under the agreement and accepted by the latter during the period in question amounted to Rs. 30,067- 9-0.

facts.text: Assistant Commissioner assessed tax of Rs. 939-10-0 and penalty of Rs. 100 under s.25 for not submitting return

anchor.surface_text: The Assistant Commissioner of Sales Tax assessed the respondent to -a tax of Rs. 939-10-0 and imposed on the respondent a penalty of Rs. 100 under s. 25 of the Act for number having submitted its return in companytravention of r. 19 of the Central Provinces and Berar Sales Tax Rules.

facts.text: Sales Tax Commissioner upheld assessment and penalty on appeal

anchor.surface_text: The respondent preferred an appeal to the Sales Tax Commissioner who upheld the Assistant Commissioners order of assessment as well as of the penalty.

facts.text: Board of Revenue treated appeal as revision under s.22(5) r.57, upheld assessment, remitted penalty

anchor.surface_text: The respondent preferred what in form appeared to be a second appeal to the Board of Revenue. As, however, there companyld be numbersecond appeal under s. 22 4  of the Act, the Board treated the memorandum of appeal as an application for revision under sub-s. 5 of s. 22 of the Act read with r. 57. Both the members of the, Board of Revenue came to the same companyclusion, namely, that the sales were liable to assessment under the Act, but the reasonings adopted by them were somewhat different.

facts.text: High Court held sales did not take place in Central Provinces and Berar, not liable to tax

anchor.surface_text: In its judgment dated June 29, 1954, the High Court took the view that the sales in question did number take place in the Central Provinces and Berar and companysequently were number sales within the meaning of the Act and, therefore, number liable to tax.

facts.text: Commissioner of Sales Tax appealed to Supreme Court after special leave

anchor.surface_text: The effect of the answers being to nullify the assessment order, the Commissioner of Sales Tax has companye up on appeal before us after obtaining special leave of this Court.

facts.text: No evidence that particular logs were in existence in Central Provinces in form of logs at date of contract

anchor.surface_text: because under the Explanation the goods, in respect of which the companytract of sale is made, must, at the date of the companytract be in existence in the Central Provinces, that is to say, that the goods must at the date of the companytract be there in the form in which they are agreed to be sold and there was numberevidence, in the present case, for this.

facts.text: Contract for unascertained goods, no controversy

anchor.surface_text: There is also numbercontroversy between the parties that at the date when this agreement was entered into, the logs were unascertained goods.

facts.text: WIMCO representative not present on all occasions of loading

anchor.surface_text: It has been found as a fact that WIMCOs representative was number present on all occasions when sawar logs used to be loaded on the railway wagons.

issues.text: whether the respondent is liable to pay any sales tax under the Act

anchor.surface_text: The question for our decision is whether the respondent is liable to pay any sales tax under the Act. It will be convenient at this stage to refer to the relevant provisions of law applicable to the facts of this case. Section 4 of that Act is the charging section.

issues.text: Does the sum of Rs. 30,067-9-0 represent the prices of logs sold by the respondent within the Central Provinces ?

anchor.surface_text: Therefore, the question arises Does the sum of Rs. 30,067-9-0 represent the prices of logs sold by the respondent within the Central Provinces ? Sale being the transfer of property in the goods agreed to be sold, we have to enquire if the property in the goods

issues.text: When did that agreement to sell unascertained goods become a sale and where did such sale take place ? In other words, when and where did the property in those goods pass from the respondent to WIMCO ?

anchor.surface_text: The question is When did that agreement to sell unascertained goods become a sale and where did such sale take place ? In other words, when and where did the property in those goods pass from the respondent to WIMCO ? The transfer of property in the goods as between the seller and buyer is dealt with in Ch. III of the Sale of Goods Act.

issues.text: Did the agreements of the kind on record the one dated 18-10-40 and the other dated 2-3-45constitute contracts of sale-either express or implied -in respect of sawar wood supplied by the assessee to WIMCO?

anchor.surface_text: On the application of the respondent under s. 23(1) of the Act, the Board of Revenue submitted to the High Court a statement of case raising the following questions- Did the agreements of the kind on record the one dated 18-10-40 and the other dated 2-3-45constitute contracts of sale-either express or implied -in respect of sawar wood supplied by the assessee to WIMCO?

issues.text: If the answer to question No. I be in the affirmative, did the contracts relate to specific or ascertained goods or to unascertained or future goods?

anchor.surface_text: If the answer to question No. I be in the affirmative, did the contracts relate to specific or ascertained goods or to unascertained or future goods? holdings.text: The property in the logs did not pass to WIMCO at the railway stations in the Central Provinces but at Ambernath upon inspection, measurement and acceptance by WIMCO's Factory Manager.
holdings.reasoning_summary: Prima facie effect of ss.23,33,39 SOGA displaced by contrary intention shown in contract clauses 2,6,7 reserving right of rejection, measurement and payment at Ambernath; buyer unconditionally appropriates there with seller's assent.

holdings.text: Explanation II to s.2(g) of the Act requires the goods to be actually in existence in the Central Provinces at the date of the contract in the form in which they are agreed to be sold; there was no evidence of this in the present case.

anchor.surface_text: because under the Explanation the goods, in respect of which the contract of sale is made, must, at the date of the contract be in existence in the Central Provinces, that is to say, that the goods must at the date of the contract be there in the form in which they are agreed to be sold and there was no evidence, in the present case, for this.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Direct textual reading of Explanation II combined with absence of evidence that specific sawar logs existed in CP as logs at January 1948 contract date.

holdings.text: The agreement between respondent and WIMCO was not in respect of standing timber but for supply of sawar logs, with no provision for severance before sale.
holdings.reasoning_summary: Contract terms examined; no mention of standing trees or severance, only logs despatch.

holdings.text: The sales in question did not take place within the Central Provinces and Berar and are not liable to tax under the Act.

anchor.surface_text: Therefore, the decision of the High Court cannot be assailed but must be accepted as well-founded in fact and in law.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Property passed outside province per SOGA application to facts; Explanation II inapplicable due to evidentiary failure; affirms High Court.
